data.title: Historical Events on January 25
data.meta_description: Historical events for the 25th of January. See what famous, interesting and notable events happened throughout history on January 25.
data.text:
Emperor Claudius

After a night of negotiation, Claudius is accepted as Roman Emperor by the Senate

Godfried II the Young becomes Duke of Brabant

King Edward III

King Edward III accedes to the English throne aged 14, after his mother Isabella of France, and her lover Roger Mortimer depose his father Edward II

Friuli Earthquake in |European southern Alps measuring approximately 6.9, largely destroys Villach, killing 5,000

Alfonso II succeeds his father as King of Naples

City of São Paulo founded in Brazil

1554 Sir Thomas Wyatt gathers an army in Kent, rebels against Queen Mary

Battle at Talikota, India: Deccan sultanate destroys Vijayanagar's army and the last Hindu kingdom of Southern India

Battle of Mikatagahara

Battle of Mikatagahara, in Japan; Takeda Shingen defeats Tokugawa Ieyasu

Pieter van den Broecke arrives at Arabian port of Mocha, will be first Dutchman to establish trade links between East India Company and Yemen and taste coffee [1]

Bossuet's First Thesis

French theologian Jacques-Bénigne Bossuet obtains his first thesis in theology with Louis II de Bourbon, Prince of Condé, as a witness

Duchy of Savoy orders expulsion or conversion of non-Catholic householders in Waldensian communities in Piedmont

Peter's Church Reforms

Tsar Peter the Great makes the Moscow patriarchate and Russian Orthodox Church subordinate to the state

Moscow University Founded

Moscow University is established by Elizabeth of Russia and founded by Mikhail Lomonosov on Tatiana Day

Americans drag a cannon up a hill of Kingsbridge Road in the Bronx, New York to fight the British, giving added significance to the area's historic name of Greate Gunn Hill; the name of the road was changed to Gun Hill Road in 1875

Shays' Rebellion suffers a setback when debt-ridden farmers, led by Capt Daniel Shays, fail to capture an arsenal at Springfield, Massachusetts

The London Corresponding Society is founded.

1st US patent for a seeding machine, Eliakim Spooner, Vermont

President Napoleon

Napoleon Bonaparte elected president of Italian (Cisalpine) Republic

La Cenerentola

Gioachino Rossini's opera "La Cenerentola" (Cinderella) premieres in Rome

University of Virginia Chartered

University of Virginia chartered by Commonwealth of Virginia, with Thomas Jefferson one of its founders

1st US engineering college opens, Rensselaer Polytechnic, Troy, NY

Vincenzo Bellini's opera "I Puritani" premieres in Paris

Talbot Exhibits Photos

William Henry Fox Talbot exhibits early photographs to the Royal Institution in the UK

Wilkes Identifies Antarctica

American naval expedition under Charles Wilkes is first to identify Antarctica as a new continent

Recontre between Reps Weller & Shriver, US House of Representative

Bednost ne Porok

Aleksandr Ostrovsky's play "Bednost ne Porok" premieres in Moscow

Battle of Seattle; skirmish between settlers & Indians

Wedding March

Felix Mendelssohn's "Wedding March" first played, at wedding of Queen Victoria's daughter Princess Victoria, to crown prince of Prussia

Augusta Arsenal seized by the Confederacy in Georgia (US Civil War)

General Joseph Hooker replaces Burnside as head of Army of Potomac

CSS Shenandoah arrives in Melbourne, Australia

Soda fountain patented by Gustavus Dows

Anti-slavery society forms in New York

Electoral Commission

Congress establishes the Electoral Commission to determine the disputed presidential election between Rutherford B. Hayes and Samuel J. Tilden

The Bulgarian National Bank is founded

Oriental Telephone Company

Thomas Edison and Alexander Graham Bell form the Oriental Telephone Company.

Bilu, a Russian Zionist organization, forms

Saugefleurie

Vincent d'Indy's symphonic poem "Saugefleurie" premieres with the Concerts Lamoureux in Paris

Bly Beats Verne's Fogg

Journalist Nellie Bly beats the fictitious journey of Jules Verne's Phileas Fogg around the world by 8 days (72 days)

National Afro-American League

National Afro-American League founded in Chicago by Timothy Thomas Fortune, one of earliest civil rights organizations in America

1890 United Mine Workers of America forms

Corbett vs. Mitchell

In his only successful title defense, James J Corbett KOs English champion Charley Mitchell in 3 rounds at the Duvall Athletic Club, Jacksonville, Florida for the world heavyweight boxing title

New Haven Symphony Orchestra of Connecticut performs its first concert

Aleksandr Skriabin's 2nd Symphony in C premieres in St Petersburg

179 die in coal mine explosion at Cheswick, Pennsylvania

1904 John Millington Synge's play "Riders to the Sea" premieres in Dublin

Pelleas und Melissande

Arnold Schoenberg's symphonic poem "Pelleas und Melissande" premieres at the Musikverein in Vienna, Austria

Del Valle Inclans "El Marqués de Bradomin" premieres in Madrid

Julia Ward Howe is first woman elected to National Institute of Arts & Letters (USA)

John Blockx's opera "Baldie" premieres in Antwerp

Elektra

Richard Strauss' one-act opera "Elektra" premieres in Dresden

1st stumping by a 12th man in Tests (N C Tufnell, SAf v Eng)

1910 Children initiate idea of planting trees in Jerusalem

Smuts-Gandhi Agreement Endorsed

An Indian mass meeting in Durban, South Africa unanimously endorses the agreement between General Jan Smuts and Mahatma Gandhi regarding voluntary registration, poll tax, recognition of Indian marriages and other matters

Giordano, Sardou & Moreau's opera "Madame Sans Gêne" premieres in NYC

1915 Transcontinental telephone service officially inaugurated as Alexander Graham Bell in NYC calls Thomas Watson in San Francisco, California during the Panama–Pacific International Exposition

Montenegro surrenders to Austria-Hungary

Russia declared a republic of Soviets

Founding of League of Nations, 1st meeting 1 year later

1919 The Hotel Pennsylvania, at the time the world's largest, opens in Manhattan

Theater Premiere

Karel Čapek's play "R.U.R." premieres in Prague, introduces the word "robot"

NVV donates 100,000 guilders to mine workers of Ruhrgebied

1st Winter Olympics

1st Winter Olympic Games open in Chamonix, France

1st commencement exercises at Hebrew U in Jerusalem

1st broadcast of "Guiding Light" on NBC radio

1937 Miami-to-Tampa bus overturned in a canal, kills 13

Ian Hay's "Bachelor Born" premieres in NYC

1st US Nuclear Fission Experiment

1st nuclear fission experiment (splitting of a uranium atom) in the US, in basement of Pupin Hall, Columbia University by a team including Enrico Fermi

1939 Earthquake hits Chillan Chile, 10,000 killed

Louis vs. Lewis

In only the second World Heavyweight C'ship fight between two black boxers, Joe Louis KOs John Henry Lewis in 1 at Madison Square Garden, NYC

Nazi decrees establishment of Jewish ghetto in Lodz Poland

Roman Catholic Diocese of Honolulu

Pope Pius XII elevates the Apostolic Vicariate of the Hawaiian Islands to the dignity of a diocese. It becomes the Roman Catholic Diocese of Honolulu.

Rommel Reaches Msus

German Field Marshall Rommel's African corps reach Msus in Libya

Grand Rapids, Michigan, becomes 1st US city to fluoridate its water

1945 Japanese occupiers of Batavia arrest Indo-European youths

1945 NY Yankees sold by Ruppert estate to construction magnate Del Webb and partners Dan Topping and Larry MacPhail for $2.8 million

1945 West Africa 82nd division occupies Myohaung, Burma

Richard Strauss' composition "Metamorphosen" premieres with the Collegium Musicum in Zürich

1946 United Mine Workers union rejoins American Federation of Labor

1st Emmy Awards: Shirley Dinsdale & Pantomime Quiz (KTLA) win

First Israeli Election

First Israeli election won by David Ben-Gurion's Mapai party

73°F (23°C) highest temperature ever recorded in Cleveland in January

Benaud Debuts

Test debut of great Australian cricket captain (62 Tests) and broadcaster Richie Benaud, v West Indies at the SCG

WABI TV channel 5 in Bangor, ME (CBS) begins broadcasting

1953 Yuri Sergejev skates world record 500m in 40.9 sec

Columbia University scientists develop an atomic clock accurate to within one second in 300 years

1955 Jill Kinmont hits a tree & breaks her back in Snow Cup Ski Race

1955 Russia ends state of war with Germany

1955 US & Panama sign canal treaty

96.5 cm (38.0") of rainfall in a day, Kilauea Plantation, Hawaii (state record, until 2018)

FBI arrests Jack & Myra Sobel, charged with spying for USSR

1st transcontinental commercial jet flight (American) (LA to NY for $301)

2nd Vatican Council

Pope John XXIII proclaims 2nd Vatican council

Chamberlain's Record Rookie Score

Wilt Chamberlain scores 58 points, the most ever by an NBA rookie, as Philadelphia Warriors beat Detroit Pistons, 127-117 at Bethlehem, PA

1st Live Presidential News Conference

First live, nationally televised presidential news conference, held by JFK

1961 Military coup in El Salvador

101 Dalmatians

Walt Disney's animated film "101 Dalmatians", based on the novel by Dodie Smith and directed by Clyde Geronimi and Hamilton Luske is released in the US

Echo 2, US communications satellite launched

1964 Nike athletics company founded in Oregon as Blue Ribbon Sports by University of Oregon track athlete Phil Knight and his coach, Bill Bowerman [1]

1964 The Beatles get their first US #1, "I Want to Hold your Hand" (Cashbox)

WCMC (now WMGM) TV channel 40 in Wildwood, NJ (NBC) 1st broadcast

Risse St in Bronx named

1968 Robert Anderson's "I Never Sang for My Father" premieres in NYC

US-North Vietnamese peace talks begin in Paris

M*A*S*H

Dark comedy film "M*A*S*H", directed by Robert Altman, starring Donald Sutherland and Elliott Gould, and based on novel by Richard Hooker, premieres (Palme d'Or 1970)

Manson Convicted

Charles Manson and three female followers are convicted of the Tate-LaBianca murders

1971 Himachal Pradesh becomes 18th Indian state

Ugandan Coup d'état

Military coup in Uganda under Major General Idi Amin

Eisenhower Dollar

Philadelphia mint's 1st trial strike of Eisenhower dollar

Chichester-Clark Pressured

The 170 delegates of the Ulster Unionist Council (UUC) call for the resignation of Northern Ireland Prime Minister James Chichester-Clark

1971 WHMB TV channel 40 in Indianapolis, IN (IND) begins broadcasting

1st Heterotopic Heart Transplant

Dr. Christiaan Barnard transplants 1st heterotopic heart transplant (adding donor heart without removal of old)

Kroc Buys Padres

Ray Kroc, CEO of McDonald's buys San Diego Padres baseball team for $12 million

Rahman Disposed

Bangladeshi parliament disposes of premier Sheikh Mujibur Rahman

Muriel Humphrey (D-Mn) appointed to fill late husband's Senate seat

1st documented case of a robot killing a human in US

1979 22.2-km Oshimizu railroad tunnel holed through, central Honshu, Japan

John Paul II's 1st Overseas Trip

Pope John Paul II's 1st overseas trip as supreme pontiff

Bani Sadr elected president of Iran

1980 Dutch government demands boycott of Olympics

1980 Highest speed attained by a warship, 167 kph, USN hovercraft

McCartney Released From Jail

Paul McCartney is released from jail in Tokyo and deported

Iran Hostage Crisis

52 Americans held hostage by Iran for 444 days arrived back in US

Mao Widow's Death Sentence

Mao's widow Jiang Qing sentenced to death as one of the "Gang of Four" (later commuted to life in prison)

1981 Super Bowl XV, Louisiana Superdome, New Orleans, LA: Oakland Raiders beat Philadelphia Eagles, 27-10; MVP: Jim Plunkett, Oakland, QB

China's supreme court commutes Chiang Ch'ing's death sentence to life

1983 Infrared telescope satellite launched into polar orbit

"Black & Blue" premieres in Paris

Coffey Sets Record

Edmonton's Paul Coffey sets NHL record for defensemen with a point in his 28th consecutive game, as the Oilers beat the visiting LA Kings, 5-2

1986 General Tito Okello's government flees Kampala, Uganda

Super Bowl XXI

Super Bowl XXI, Rose Bowl, Pasadena, CA: NY Giants beat Denver Broncos, 39-20; MVP: Phil Simms, NY Giants, QB

Longest winless streak in Toronto Maple Leaf history (15 games)

1988 Ramsewak Shankar sworn in as President of Suriname

Rather and Bush Clash

US Vice President George H. W. Bush and Dan Rather famously clash on "CBS Evening News" as Rather attempts to question Bush about his role in Iran-Contra affair

Augusto Alcalde, 1st South American Zen teacher, receives Dharma Transmission

Lemieux Sets Record

Mario Lemieux scores a goal and 3 assists in Penguins' 5-4 win over Winnipeg in Pittsburgh; sets NHL record by picking up a point in 14 consecutive games; record stands for 10 years

Jordan's 10,000th Point

Michael Jordan scores his 10,000th NBA point in his 5th season

Steinbrenner Meets Pope

NY Yankees owner George Steinbrenner meets with Pope John Paul II

Avianca Flight 052 runs out of fuel and crashes into a hillside at Cove Neck, New York, killing 8 of the 9 crew members and 65 of the 149 passengers on board

Noriega to Miami Jail

Former Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega is transferred to a Miami jail

1990 Honduras becomes a member of the Berne Convention copyright treaty

1990 The Burns' Day windstorm storm hits northwestern Europe

Manuel Noriega is given access to assets frozen by US government

1991 Soap opera "Generation's" last episode after a 2½ year run

Hull's 50 Points Record

St. Louis right wing Brett Hull scores twice in Blues' 9-4 win at Detroit, to give him 50 goals in 49 games; becomes 3rd player in NHL history with 50 goals in less than 50 games

Jansen's 500m Record

Dan Jansen skates world record 500m in 36.41"

1992 Hubble space telescope optics finds NGC3862/3C264

Five people were shot outside CIA headquarters in Langley, Virginia resulting in two murders.

1993 Puerto Rico adds English as its 2nd official language

1993 Sears announces it is closing its catalog sales department after 97 years

1994 Mine fire at Asansol, India, kills 55

1994 US space probe Clementine launched from Vandenberg Air Force Base, California

Chicago Blackhawks beat Edmonton Oilers, 5-1 in the first NHL game in their new home, the United Center; defenseman Chris Chelios leads scoring with a goal and 2 assists

1995 Jacques Santer of Luxembourg succeeds Jacques Delors of France as President of the European Commission

Ottawa Senators set an NHL record with 16th consecutive home game without a win (0-15-1) in a 4-2 loss to Detroit at the Palladium; old record (15) shared by 1928 Black Hawks & 1939 Canadiens

In a high profile NHL trade, San Jose obtain future Hockey Hall of Fame goaltender Ed Belfour from Chicago in exchange for goaltender Chris Terreri, Ulf Dahlen, Michal Sykora and a conditional pick in 1998 Entry Draft

"Patti LaBelle On Broadway" closes at St James Theater NYC

Queen Mother's Hip Replacement

Britain's Queen Mother gets an emergency hip replacement aged 97

1998 Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam mount a suicide attack on Sri Lanka's Temple of the Tooth in Kandy, killing 8 people and injuring 25 others

1998 Pope John Paul II visits Cuba and demands the release of political prisoners; he also condemns US moves to isolate the country

Posh and Becks Get Engaged

Spice Girl Victoria Adams (Posh) and soccer player David Beckham get engaged

1998 Super Bowl XXXII, Qualcomm Stadium, San Diego, CA: Denver Broncos beat Green Bay Packers, 31-24; MVP: Terrell Davis, Denver RB

After an inquiry into a corruption scandal, 6 International Olympic Committee members are expelled

1999 Earthquake hits Colombia, South America, killing around 300 and injuring 1000

A 50-year-old Douglas DC-3 crashes near Ciudad Bolivar, Venezuela killing 24

Wikipedia switches to the new version of its software ("Phase II") aka Magnus Manske Day.

A stampede at the Mandher Devi temple in Mandhradevi in India kills at least 258

Three independent observing campaigns announce the discovery of OGLE-2005-BLG-390Lb through gravitational microlensing, the first cool rocky/icy extrasolar planet around a main-sequence star.

Ethiopian Airlines Flight 409 crashes into the Mediterranean Sea shortly after take-off from Beirut Rafic Hariri International Airport, killing all 90 people on-board.

Egyptian Revolution of 2011 begins with a series of street demonstrations, rallies, acts of civil disobedience, labor strikes and violent clashes in Cairo, Alexandria and other major cities

2011 UK announces it had a shock economic contraction of 0.5% in Q4 2010, due to severe winter weather and budget cuts implemented by the coalition government

50 people are killed and 90 are injured in a prison riot in Barquisimeto, Venezuela

2013 6 civilians and 1 police officer are shot dead and 456 people are injured during a nationwide protest against Egypt’s 2011 revolution

2013 8 people are killed by 2 car bombs in Golan Heights, Syria

2013 Initial GDP figures for the fourth quarter of 2012 show the UK economy shrank by 0.3% raising fears of a triple dip recession

2013 Islamist forces are driven out of Hombori by the Malian army

2013 Tropical cyclone Oswald makes landfall in Queensland, Australia, causing mass flooding

British rowing team becomes first female crew and first crew of four to cross the Pacific, San Francisco to Cairns in 257 days

Kisenosato becomes the 1st Japanese home-grown sumo champion since 1998 when he is made yokozuna, 72nd Grand Champion

Doomsday clock moved by 30 seconds to 2 minutes to midnight by Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, closest since 1950s

2018 Nigerian author Chimamanda Ngozi asked "are there any bookshops in Nigeria?" in controversial French interview

At least 20 people have died this week in Venezuelan anti-government protests according to the UN

2019 Roger Stone, political lobbyist for Donald Trump, is arrested as part of Mueller investigation for obstruction of justice, witness tampering and making false statements

2019 Tailing dam for an iron ore mine in Brumadinho, south-eastern Brazil, collapses killing at least 110 with 238 missing

Severe rainstorms cause landslides and floods in Brazil's Minas Gerais state, killing at least 30

1st Female Treasury Secretary

Janet Yellen is confirmed as the first female treasury secretary by the US Senate

Australian government buys the copyright to the Aboriginal flag designed by artist Harold Thomas for A$20 million (US$14m) [1]

2022 People smuggling boat reported to have capsized in the Florida Straits with the loss of 38 lives

2022 Philadelphia Flyers defenseman Keith Yandle becomes NHL's new "Iron Man" with his 965th consecutive regular-season game, breaking Doug Jarvis's all-time record, in a 4-3 loss at the New York Islanders [1]

America and Germany announce decision to send powerful battle tanks (US 31, Germany 14) to Ukraine to fight Russia invasion

Jacinda Ardern Resigns

Chris Hipkins is sworn in as Prime Minister of New Zealand, following the resignation of Jacinda Ardern

British researchers Christopher Marsh and Angela McShane launch website 100Ballads.org detailing top-selling broadside ballads of 17th century England, including images of original lyric sheets, and new musical recordings of the very old pop songs [1]
